docs.lead_paragraph: A CHILD'S death during surgery is frightening and rare, and if any good can come from it it is to prevent further tragedies. A case in point arose in New York when 4-year-old Harry Donnelly of Somers died after routine low-risk out-patient surgery to remove his adenoids and insert tiny tubes in his eardrums to drain fluid at Hudson Valley Hospital Center in Peekskill in February 1997.

headline.main: Boy's Death in Surgery Is Lesson on Nonprescription Drugs

docs.abstract: Alert goes out to surgeons and anesthesiologists after a four-year-old boy dies following routine low-risk out-patient surgery to remove his adenoids and insert tiny tubes in his eardrums to drain fluid; surgery took place at Hudson Valley Hospital Center in Peekskill in February 1997; state health officials determine that most probable cause of death was adverse reaction to nonprescription drug, phenylephrine, same medication that is sold over the counter as Neo-Synephrine; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Five months after becoming the only place in the world to have legal doctor-assisted suicide, Oregon has produced a detailed manual on how doctors can end a life, and the state has decided that taxpayers should pay for it when the patient is poor. But perhaps the biggest surprise in trying to go where no state in this country has ever gone before is that so few terminally ill people in Oregon, if any, have thus far decided go through the formal procedures to kill themselves publicly.

headline.main: No One Rushing in Oregon To Use a New Suicide Law

docs.abstract: Doctor-assisted suicide has been legal in Oregon for five months, but no one has yet exercised his or her right to it; confusion persists among doctors, pharmacists and nurses over their roles in helping a patient to die (M)
